item.title: Easiest ways to learn something
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
The easiest ways to learn how do to something better:

  • do something for the first time
  • Do something 1000 times. You get better over time.
  • Mess up doing something: this is how you realize your initial assumptions were wrong and you overcome beginners luck.
  • Do something fast: You see what you do more efficiently.
  • Do the same thing with new inputs: serve a new customer, try on new shoes for walking.
  • Watch someone do the same thing you‚Äôve done 50 times: you have all the context and you‚Äôre primed to observe new ideas.

This is life experience, it turns out. Doing a lot of stuff on repeat, watching others do it, mess up doing it, or do it slightly differently‚Ä¶

item.title: Tracing
item.description:
‚ÄúTell her you traced that‚Äù

my daughter had just asked me if I drew this. I said yes. But I omitted some details.

What does it matter I traced it? I wanted a picture that didn‚Äôt look like two potatos.

Nowadays, the question of: ‚Äúdid you draw that‚Äù and ‚Äúdid you actually write that‚Äù will perhaps become more relevant.

I‚Äôve never coded without using Google. Now I don‚Äôt code without AI. Is that cheating? Am I tracing??

Ultimately, nobody cares how it was made. Just that it was made to spec.

Similarly, a relative likes to bow hunt. Why? It‚Äôs more fun than a rifle. More of a challenge.

I didn‚Äôt want a challenge. I wanted a better drawing. So I traced.

In the future, we‚Äôll still write ‚Äúby hand‚Äù. But not to create a great product. But because it‚Äôs meaningful to experience as a human.

item.title: Chicken Nugget A B testing
item.description:
Why cutting chicken nuggets for my 2y old is an optimization problem, and how social media companies use these principles:

Objective: maximize my 2 year olds caloric intake

  • Inputs: chicken nugget size.

  • Cut two nuggets four ways: 8 pieces.

  • Cut two nuggets two ways: 4 pieces.

Will the kid eat 5 small pieces or 3 big ones?

On one hand, he eats 62.5% of nuggets. On the other, 75%. But maybe he only eats two halves - that drops him to 50% consumption.

What gets you watching one more YouTube, one more Spotify song, one more TikTok? One more LinkedIn post?

Do people sign off after 5 posts? One post? If we slide a video into the fifth spot after the first four posts, do they engage? If they engage with the video do they come back tomorrow or in a week?

Everything‚Äôs an optimization. Even cutting nuggets. Your mind just does this subconsciously.

item.title: Scientific method
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I use these seven steps to the scientific method every single day:

  1. What‚Äôs the problem?
  2. Hypothesis: What‚Äôs the believed answer?
  3. Metrics: how do I measure with data?
  4. Methods: how do I test the belief?
  5. Findings: what are the unemotional facts?
  6. Discussion: what are my opinions about the findings? (These are usually more hypotheses.)
  7. Next steps: self explanatory ü§£

It helps me think more clearly when diving into data! Hope it helps.

item.title: Data science structure
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
Over my career I‚Äôve thought a lot about ‚Äúwhere should a data scientist sit in an org?‚Äù üëá 5 lessons from what I‚Äôve learned after working in 6 very different companies.

  1. DS under an MBA: maybe okay, probably bound for failure.
  2. DS under the PM: def bound for failure.
  3. DS under the DS: good for the junior in the short term.
  4. DS under Eng: good.
  5. DS under a people manager, but works closely integrated team with a DS-experiences tech lead: best.

Interdisciplinary teams do the best work. It maximizes labor efficiency to have engineers, PMs, and DS‚Äôs working on the same problem but doing different things.

When you federate DS, they don‚Äôt care as much about what they‚Äôre working on. The incentives are off.

When a DS works for a PM the PM will make wild assumptions about what they should do. PMs oversimplify problems and DS find that unsatisfying.

DS reporting to DS means you throw stuff over the fence and the Eng do the real work. And the Eng don‚Äôt capture all the nuance the DS would like to implement.

DS reporting to business types is unfulfilling because DS love technical stuff.

best scenario? Have a DS work in a pod with experienced tech leads. DS reports (HR purposes) to someone outside of the team who can give them guidance but is incapable of micromanaging them.

item.title: Forget Pythonic. Write code that works
item.description:
For the Python nerds: I‚Äôve seen data scientists bashing notebooks for years. I was one of them.

Then I learned yesterday about nbdev and how Jeremy Howard and folks at Nixtla are building production grade software using‚Ä¶notebooks.

I was taken aback by Jeremy‚Äôs YouTube ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt write code like most Python programmers, but I have a reason for how I write it‚Äù.

I was also shocked how easy it was to read Nixtla‚Äôs documentation and source code. Shouldn‚Äôt that be the goal??

Unit tests at the bottom of the Python files where the functions are defined. Wait‚Ä¶that makes a ton of sense.

Wirh nbdev there‚Äôs no major emphasis on pep8. No black formatting. No like wrap at 80 characters.

And I realized: we put so much emphasis on convention and doing what others are doing.

I‚Äôm not saying pep8 or black are wrong. I like them. But Python is just a language. Don‚Äôt get sucked into ‚Äúbeing pythonic‚Äù. If the code works, and it creates value, it serves its purpose.

I come from R where there are so many ‚Äúdialects‚Äù. Compare base R vs the tidyverse. Worlds apart in how they build and test their code.

So‚Ä¶make your own dialect. Just don‚Äôt waste time trying to keep up with all the formatters and linters out there. Because who cares? It‚Äôs your code.

It‚Äôs okay to have you or your team have your own style.

item.title: 10 steps to optimize anything
item.dc:creator: Bryan Whiting
item.description:
I love-hate goal setting. Here are 10 steps I often fail at in how I try to breakdown and achieve goals, but hey, this is LinkedIn so I‚Äôll share‚Ä¶

  1. Objective: Define your ‚Äúwhere you are going‚Äù and your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù.
  2. Principles: Decide what‚Äôs worth it in how you pursue your where/why.
  3. Key Result: Measure the goal numerically 1-3 ways. Too many is too confusing.
  4. KR-Drivers: Identify the key drivers that affect the goal.
  5. Hypothesize: Use data/intuition to guess what will drive increases in KR-drivers.
  6. Experiment: Try 2 approaches, manipulate the drivers in big or minor ways.
  7. Track: Measure/track/Log what‚Äôs needed to measure if your hypothesis was valid or rejected.
  8. Analyze: make minor tweaks in the drivers and measure statistically significant changes.
  9. Conclude: Which direction will increase your KR. Consider alternate paths if the experiment didn‚Äôt yield good results.
  10. Periodic Evaluation: At a pre-determined cadence (1 wk, 6 wk, quarter), choose if your KR is helping you achieve your objective. 

A few lessons learned as a professional experimenter:

  • Tracking is not the key result. Don‚Äôt confuse them. Too many people  track habits for no reason (I‚Äôm guilty of this 100%)
  • KR‚Äôs have no purpose if you don‚Äôt have an objective. You want 100k ffollowers? 100k revenue? They don‚Äôt mean anything until you know what you‚Äôre going to do with it. More fame/money doesn‚Äôt equal more life satisfaction. Lots of unhappy/depressed rich/famous people.
  • ‚ÄúExperimentation‚Äù early into defining a product should be massive swings. Find the ‚Äúlowest hanging fruit‚Äù, make the biggest changes.
  • Have principles to guide your KR‚Äôs. If you don‚Äôt
  • Have Anti-KR‚Äôs - things you won‚Äôt do. This is the hardest. If you have 10 KR‚Äôs, perhaps KR‚Äôs 2-10 should be all anti-KR‚Äôs. Otherwise, you‚Äôll get distracted on 2 despite you knowing 1 is most important.
  • A rising tide lifts all ships: By improving one KR, you may be sacrificing improving another. But more likely you‚Äôll actually improve all KR‚Äôs, because they‚Äôre usually correlated.

Easy Example: ‚ÄúI want to be healthier‚Äù

  1. Objective: I want more energy to be able to devote it to my kids.

  2. Principles: 

  3. I will not hurt my body by doing unnecessary XYZ

  4. I‚Äôm not going to kill myself. I‚Äôm going to keep this simple.

  5. KR:  (Write down 10, pick the one that will obviate the rest)

  6. Gain 10 lbs of muscle

  7. Eat 100g of protein a day

  8. Sleep 8 hours a day

  9. Meditate 20 minutes a day

  10. KR-drivers for gaining 10 lbs of muscle:

  11. Lift weights

  12. Focus on quads

  13. Focus on upper body

  14. Hypothesize: If I go to the gym for 10 minutes for 28 days and do 30 exercises a day, I‚Äôll gain muscle. 

  15. Experiment: I‚Äôll keep my diet the same - including the popcorn. I‚Äôll focus my mental energy on clearing my calendar and getting out the door to the gym. The ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù experiment is what I‚Äôve done the last 28 days‚Ä¶not worked out ü§£

  16. Track: 

    1. Day 1: I‚Äôll weight myself, write a journal about how I feel. Perhaps ask myself some questions.
    2. Did I go to the gym for 10 minutes? I‚Äôll keep a piece of paper and a pen taped to my mirror or on my nightstand. Checkbox. Don‚Äôt track anything else. This is my one focus right now.

  17. Analyze: on day 28, I‚Äôll weigh myself again. 

  18. Conclude: Did this 28-day challenge change how I felt? Be honest: it might not. Perhaps I can get on my bike, or hike, or do pushups every day instead.

  19. Periodic evaluation: every 2 months I‚Äôll investigate how my energy is.

your goal isn‚Äôt to gain/lose weight. Your goal is to feel better about your health. Your key result is a number on a scale going up/down.
